greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = n / (gcd(n,2) * gcd(n,3)).
comment: a(n+2) is absolute value of numerator of determinant of n X n matrix with M(i,j) = 2/(i(i+1)) if i=j otherwise 1. - _Alexander Adamchuk_, May 19 2006

In addition to being multiplicative, this sequence is also a strong divisibility sequence, that is, gcd(a(n),a(m)) = a(gcd(n, m)) for n, m >= 1. In particular, it follows that a(n) is a divisibility sequence: if n divides m then a(n) divides a(m). - _Peter Bala_, Feb 20 2019
link: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..1000
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (0,0,0,0,0,2,0,0,0,0,0,-1).
formula: Multiplicative with a(2^e)=2^(e-1), a(3^e)=3^(e-1), a(p^e)=p^e, p>3. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Sep 09 2004
a(n) divides n. a(6k) = k for integer k>0. a(p^k) = p^k for prime p>3 and integer k>0. - _Alexander Adamchuk_, Sep 20 2006
a(n) = denominator((4*n-6)/n), n >= 2, with a(1) = 1. - _Johannes W. Meijer_, Dec 19 2012
a(n) = 2*a(n-6) - a(n-12) for n >= 12. - _Robert Israel_, Aug 06 2015
a(n) = n/b(n), where b(n) is the purely periodic sequence [1,2,3,2,1,6,...] with period 6.
maple: a := proc(n): if n = 1 then 1 else denom((4*n-6)/n) fi: end: seq(a(n), n=1..77); # _Johannes W. Meijer_, Dec 19 2012
mathematica: Numerator[Table[(-1)^(n+1) Det[ DiagonalMatrix[ Table[ 2/(i(i+1)) - 1, {i, 1, n-2} ] ] + 1 ], {n, 30} ]] (* _Alexander Adamchuk_, May 19 2006 *)
program: (Sage) [lcm(n,6)/6 for n in range(1, 78)] # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Jun 07 2009
(PARI) { for (n=1, 1000, write("b060789.txt", n, " ", n / (gcd(n, 2) * gcd(n, 3))); ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Jul 11 2009
(MAGMA) I:=[1,1,1,2,5,1,7,4,3,5,11,2]; [n le 12 select I[n] else 2*Self(n-6)-Self(n-12): n in [1..80]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 07 2015
xref: Cf. other sequences given by the formula n/gcd(n,k) = numerator(n/(n + k)): A026741 (k = 2), A051176 (k = 3), A060819 (k = 4), A060791 (k = 5), A106608 thru A106612 (k = 7 thru 11), A051724 (k = 12), A106614 thru A106621 (k = 13 thru 20).
results.author: _Len Smiley_, Apr 26 2001
